data.title: File system tree does not reflect specific gitignore arrangement
data.body:
Consider the following `.gitignore` structure:

```
# Ignore parent folder contents
content/*

# Include selective folders in parent folder
!content/special-child/
!content/special-file.ext
```

In the filesystem tree, on the sidebar, the folders parent (`content/`) and respective children files/folders are marked like untracked because of the first statement.
This becomes quite confusing if the parent folder is populated with several outside dependencies and some specific folders/files with code that are tracked (i.e. their exclusion is denied) while browsing the tree.

data.title: :bug: make atom protocol urls more robust
data.body:
I wanted to bundle some fonts to my package as described here: https://atom.io/docs/v0.186.0/creating-a-package#bundle-external-resources.

It didn't work and after diving into Atom's sources I realised that the problem is translation of urls to file-system paths. In my case urls contained extra url parameters, e.g. `atom://plastic-clojurescript/fonts/eot/hack-regularoblique-webfont.eot?v=2.010`

I have modified the code to strip parts after question mark or hash from urls. That was a quick fix.

Possible future improvement could be using some robust library for proper url parsing.

data.title: Race condition when opening files leads to data loss
data.body:
I have had this problem happen in other circumstances (disconnected windows into the same file), but I seem to be able to reproduce it reliably this way.

Open a terminal, type `atom file.txt & ; atom file.txt` (make sure file.txt does not current exist)

Two windows into file.txt will open. In the top one, type some text, save and close.

The text is not reproduced in the second. Closing this window will prompt to save the file even though you have not typed anything. This will save a blank file, overwriting your text.

data.title: Ability to disable auto-indent while typing.
data.body:
More often than not Atom's auto indent feature gets auto-indentation wrong for example:

``` sh
for f in $(git show --pretty="format:" --name-only); do
  [[ "$f" ]] {
    file=$(readlink -f "$f")
    if grep -E "^$root/dockerfiles/"
    then

    fi
  }
done
```

Will always lead to anything typed after then being indented backwards all the way into the for statement.  This behavior happens quite often in bash and Ruby when working with complex sets of code where Atom expects one thing but the other is actually valid.

It would be nice to be able to disable this auto-indent in the middle of typing instead of waiting for changes to make it into a specific language, because Atom is a large project, so changes don't happen over night, but this feature would make it so that it can be fixed.

**To clarify:** I do not wish to remove auto-indentation entirely, just disable it when I start typing.  I don't need it to correct my personal indentation for me, where I choose to indent should really be my business, but when I press enter and go to a new line, indent automatically how you see fit all you want, but once I correct it and start typing, the correct behavior (IMO) would be to let me be because it's a personal choice at that point.

data.title: Building atom on Linux fails when the option “--no-parallel” isn’t available with node-gyp
data.body:
Building atom on Linux requires `node-gyp`. On my system, `node-gyp` doesn’t come with the `--no-parallel` option, which is used for example in `build/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/lib/configure.js` (once created). Building atom fails because of this, [here](http://pastebin.com/nq9B2mh2) is my initial standard output on running `./script/build`.

This is what [issue #426](https://github.com/nodejs/node-gyp/issues/426) on nodejs/node-gyp is about.

As a workaround and analogously to the hack provided there, one can comment out _any line_ saying `argv.push('--no-parallel')` in _any file_ called `configure.js` which is created before or during a build attempt (I used `find . -name "configure.js"` to find those). During my build, more files with that name have been generated (if I recall correctly – might have overlooked them), so one has to repeatedly try to build atom and repeatedly change all lines.

data.title: prevent use of socket in apm test
data.body:
When I run `apm test` while having another Atom window open (on a mac, if that matters), the new Atom instance screws with the socket file: it deletes the original socket on start [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/5e5139b753b9c24b2671064f3b1eceabb31112d9/src/browser/atom-application.coffee#L136), creates its own and deletes that on exit.

That means that after `apm test`, `atom .` no longer opens in the original (still running) window.

Even worse, during `apm test`, `atom .` will open a window in the instance running the tests, which then happily dies (taking the new window with it) when the specs are done.

Comments on the PR welcome.

data.title: Undo / redo stack should be saved between reloads.
data.body:
I'm trying to develop a plugin for Atom, but every time I reload the editor to see the new code changes, I lose the undo/redo stack.
Would be nice to be able to save it per 'session' and only clear it when the tab or editor is closed. 
I understand that reloading the editor using ctrl+alt+cmd+L is effectively closing the tabs and it could get tricky to detect if the user manually closed a tab, or chose to close all tabs, but I think it's doable.

Also, I had to disable the "Whitespace" package: https://discuss.atom.io/t/save-redo-save-redo-then-redo-did-not-work-bug/10501
In my opinion, the undo/redo stack should not be affected by packages.

data.title: Config is loaded too late in the startup process
data.body:
I have been trying to solve https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8287 but repeatedly hit a wall caused by the fact that the config is loaded very late in the startup process, after the window creation code is set up and indeed after all code in the [`browser`](https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/src/browser) source directory. This means that currently quite a few things, such as window parameters, are impossible to expose to the user through a config option.

It seems to me that loading the configuration should be _the very first thing_ happening on startup, so that all following code can take settings into account.
